translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Birth Stories (Jātakas)
The Chapter on Gandhāri
The Potter Birth Story
“In the forest, near the mango tree,
a blue-black snake, swollen with food,
I saw it, split open by the cause of fruit,
having seen that, I went for alms.

analyzed: selam su maṭṭham nara vīra niṭṭhita
translated: A well-polished stone, finished by a man,
a pair of women held it, silently;
and when a second came, there was a sound,
having seen that, I went for alms.
A bird, carrying a dead bird,
many gathered around that one,
for the sake of food, they tore it apart,
having seen that, I went for alms.
In the middle of the herd, a bull elephant,
moving, with beauty and strength,
I saw it, agitated by the cause of desire,
having seen that, I went for alms.”
“Karaṇḍaka for the Kaliṅgas,
Naggaji for the Gandhāris,
King Nimī for the Videhans,
Dummukha for the Pañcālas,
having abandoned these kingdoms,
they went forth, without possessions.

analyzed: sabbe pi me deva samā samāgatā
translated: All these, like gods, have come together;

analyzed: aggī yathā pajjalitaḥ tathā iva ime
translated: Like a blazing fire are they;
Alone I will go, O Bhaggava,
Having abandoned all desires as they arise.”

analyzed: ayam eva kālaḥ na hi aññaḥ atthi
translated: “This is the time, no other is there;
If I do not instruct you, it will be too late;
Alone I will go, O Bhaggava,
Like a bird freed from the man’s hand.”
“They know what is raw and what is cooked,
and also what is salty and what is not;
Having seen that, I went forth;
you go, I will go.”🔽The Kumbhakāra Birth Story is the third.
